snippet.textDisplay:
Despite it's flaws, what captivated me about this games story was that there was no magical cure to save her - she was dying, and that was all there was to it.

Not that I like death or anything creepy liked that - but it's just the concept of acceptance, and learning to enjoy what time they have left, together.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: @Eric C. Enjoy the ride! WA2's last boss and ending is phenomenal, nearly brings me to tears. And WA3 is an all around solid game. It has an amazing soundtrack and so much stuff to do in the game. WA3 was also one of, if not, the first cel-shaded game to come out in the US.
snippet.textOriginal: @Eric C. Enjoy the ride! WA2's last boss and ending is phenomenal, nearly brings me to tears. And WA3 is an all around solid game. It has an amazing soundtrack and so much stuff to do in the game. WA3 was also one of, if not, the first cel-shaded game to come out in the US.

snippet.textDisplay: I think this might be the series' longest track. Suzuki barely composed any VGM except for a couple tracks in this game, which are all very solid. I like his multiphase composition technique (see #191), with this theme being a perfect representation of it. It plays inside a city's ruins and if I remember correctly, each new screen starts the next phase. It's always been a favorite of mine, even if it's quite slow.
snippet.textOriginal: I think this might be the series' longest track. Suzuki barely composed any VGM except for a couple tracks in this game, which are all very solid. I like his multiphase composition technique (see #191), with this theme being a perfect representation of it. It plays inside a city's ruins and if I remember correctly, each new screen starts the next phase. It's always been a favorite of mine, even if it's quite slow.
